segment.source: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario for Application Virtualization Clients
segment.target: Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario for Application Virtualization Clients

segment.source: The Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario enables you to realize the benefits of Microsoft Application Virtualization in situations where no servers are available to support other methods of deploying your virtual applications.
segment.target: The Stand-Alone Delivery Scenario enables you to realize the benefits of Microsoft Application Virtualization in situations where no servers are available to support other methods of deploying your virtual applications.

segment.source: It is assumed that you have already installed the Application Virtualization Sequencer in preparation for the stand-alone scenario.
segment.target: It is assumed that you have already installed the Application Virtualization Sequencer in preparation for the stand-alone scenario.

segment.source: For more information, see How to Install the Application Virtualization Sequencer.
segment.target: For more information, see How to Install the Application Virtualization Sequencer.

segment.source: Provides a general overview of the benefits of a stand-alone Application Virtualization deployment scenario.
segment.target: Provides a general overview of the benefits of a stand-alone Application Virtualization deployment scenario.

segment.source: How to Manually Install the Application Virtualization Client
segment.target: How to Manually Install the Application Virtualization Client

segment.source: Provides a step-by-step procedure for installing the Application Virtualization Client software.
segment.target: Provides a step-by-step procedure for installing the Application Virtualization Client software.

segment.source: How to Publish a Virtual Application on the Client
segment.target: How to Publish a Virtual Application on the Client

segment.source: Provides command-line procedures for publishing an application package, using either Windows Installer or SFTMIME.
segment.target: Provides command-line procedures for publishing an application package, using either Windows Installer or SFTMIME.
